We should now make a golden vessel, place it in the market, fill it with fragrant water, and use it to bathe the Buddha. Distribute the fragrant water and build stupas, which may remove the disaster.

They then invited the Tathagata to bathe in fragrant water. They divided the remaining water used to bathe the World-Honored One into eighty-four thousand jeweled bottles and distributed them to eighty-four thousand countries, instructing them to build stupas, make offerings, and create blessings.
Because of the merit of building stupas and temples, the heavens rained greatly, the five grains ripened in abundance, and the people were at peace and happy.
At that time, there was a person who saw the stupas and temples, and joy arose in his heart. He then scattered a handful of flowers on the stupas, and obtained the great good reward.
The Buddha said:
With my Buddha eye, I observe that from long ago, the sandalwood-like stupas and temples have received his transformation, and they have all long since attained Buddhahood and entered nirvana.
The one who offered a handful of flowers is none other than myself.
Because of this cause and effect from my past, I have now attained Buddhahood in my final life.
Therefore, practitioners should diligently make various merits with their minds and not have a sense of inferiority towards small goodness.

78. The Causes and Conditions of the Elder Inviting ÅšÄriputra and Mahallaka (78) Once, in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, there was a great elder whose family was extremely wealthy, with immeasurable wealth and treasures. He always invited monks in the order of succession to his home for offerings.
At that time, it was ÅšÄriputra and Mahallaka's turn in the order of succession to go to the elder's home. When the elder saw them, he was overjoyed.
On that very day, merchants who had gone to sea to trade had obtained precious treasures and returned home safely.

At that time, the king of that country distributed villages and bestowed them on the elder. His wife was pregnant and gave birth to a son. All the joyous celebrations gathered at the same time. ÅšÄriputra and the others entered his home and received the elder's offerings.
After the meal, the elder served water and spread out a small seat in front of the Venerable One. ÅšÄriputra recited a spell and said:

Today is an auspicious time, a good reward, wealth, benefits, and joyful events all come together, I am overjoyed, my heart is filled with joy and delight, with a mind of faith, I give rise to thoughts of the Ten Powers, just as today, may it always be so in the future.
At that time, the elder, having heard the benediction, was greatly delighted in his heart, and immediately offered two bolts of fine silk to ÅšÄriputra, but he did not offer any to Mahallaka.
At that time, Mahallaka returned to the temple, feeling dejected, and thought to himself:
The reason why ÅšÄriputra obtained this is precisely because his benediction pleased the elder's mind, and thus he received this offering.
I should now seek this benediction.
He then said to ÅšÄriputra:
Please bestow upon me the benediction you just recited.
He immediately replied:
This benediction cannot be used all the time, there are times when it can be used and times when it cannot be used.
Mallaka earnestly requested:
Please be sure to give me the mantra.
ÅšÄriputra could not refuse his request, so he gave him the mantra.
After receiving the teaching, he immediately recited it and memorized it thoroughly. He thought to himself:
When will it be my turn to be the senior monk and use this mantra?
Then, in the order of the Sangha, he arrived at the elder's house and became the senior monk.

At that time, the elder's merchant had gone to sea and lost his precious treasures. The elder's wife was involved in a legal matter, and their son had also died. The mahÄrogiya monk recited the original mantra as usual.
At that time, the elder, having heard these words, became angry and immediately drove him out, beating him.
After being beaten in anger, he became very upset and entered the king's field of sesame, trampling the sesame plants, breaking them.
The sesame guard became angry and beat him even more, causing him great humiliation.
At that time, Mahalla, having been beaten again, asked the beater, saying:
What offense have I committed that I am beaten like this?
Then the sesame guard told him in detail about the trampling of the sesame and showed him the way.
Continuing on the road, before going a few li, he encountered someone harvesting wheat, piled up into a heap.
At that time, the custom was to circle the heap to the right, setting out food and drink, seeking abundant harvests. If one circled to the left, it was considered inauspicious.
At that time, Mahalla circled the wheat heap to the left. The wheat owner became angry and beat him again.
At that time, Mahalla asked again, saying:
What crime have I committed that I am beaten for no reason?
The wheat owner replied:
Why didn't you circle the wheat heap to the right, reciting the mantra 'may there be plenty'?
Because you violate our Dharma, therefore we beat you.
He then showed them the way.
A little further ahead, they encountered a funeral, circumambulating the burial mound, like the previous wheat pile, and chanted the words of blessings:
Enter more, enter more.
The funeral master became angry and grabbed him again, beating him, and said:
You see the dead and should have pity on them. You say from now on, never do this again. Why do you say 'enter more, enter more' in return?
The Mahallaka said:
From now on, I will do as you say.
They went further ahead and saw a wedding, like the teachings of the funeral director:
From now on, do not do this again.
At that time, the wedding party was angry at his doing this and beat him even more, until his head was broken.

He then continued on his way, but was beaten again and ran away in confusion. He happened to encounter someone catching geese, and in his panic and disarray, he bumped into the other person's net. Because of this, he startled the other person's geese and scattered them. The hunter became angry and caught him again, beating him with a stick.
At that time, Mahallaka, having been beaten to the point of exhaustion, said to the hunter:

I was walking on a straight path, but was tripped several times. My spirit was lost and confused, and my steps became agitated. I bumped into your net. I hope you will let me go and allow me to continue on my way.
The hunter replied:
You are extremely clumsy and foolish to the point of being like this. Why don't you crawl slowly?
He then crawled along the path as the hunter had said.
On the road, he encountered someone washing clothes. Seeing him crawling on his elbows, they thought he was trying to steal clothes, so they seized him and beat him again.
At that time, Mahallaka, having suffered to the point of extreme distress, fully explained the above events and was allowed to be released.
He went to Jetavana and told the monks:
On a previous day, I recited ÅšÄriputra's prayer and suffered greatly.
He told them how he was beaten and his body was bruised and almost lost his life.
The monks took Mahallaka to the Buddha and told him in detail about the man being beaten.
The Buddha said:
This Mahallaka not only has this kind of cause and effect today,
but also in the past, there was a princess who encountered an illness. The court astrologer divined that she needed to go to a cemetery to be cured.
At that time, the princess immediately took her attendants and went to the cemetery.
At that time, on the way, there were two merchants who saw the princess and her attendants in grand attire. They were afraid and ran to the cemetery.
One of them was the attendant of the princess and cut off her ears and nose;
One of them, having obtained a sudden fright, died and lay hidden in the corpse, pretending to be dead.
At that time, the king's daughter was about to remove the old corpse and select a fresh one whose skin was not yet rotten, to sit on it and bathe, in order to cure her illness.

When she sent someone to look, they happened to find the merchant, who touched him with his hand. His body was still warm, and they thought he was newly dead. They immediately applied mustard seeds to his body and bathed him. The pungent smell of the mustard seeds entered the merchant's nose. Although he wanted to control himself, he could not restrain himself and suddenly sneezed and came to life.
The attendants thought it was a zombie ghost that might bring them misfortune, so they closed the door and resisted. The king's daughter became anxious and grabbed him tightly, not letting go.
At that time, the merchant told the truth:
I am truly not a ghost.
The king's daughter immediately went with the merchant to the city, called out to open the city gate, and explained the truth in detail.
Although the king, the girl's father, heard her words, he still did not believe them. He adorned his troops, opened the door to go and see, and only then realized she was not a ghost.
At that time, the king said:
The body of a woman does not appear twice.
He then gave his daughter in marriage to him.
The merchant was overjoyed, and his good fortune was immeasurable.
The Buddha said:
The merchant who obtained the king's daughter at that time is ÅšÄriputra.
The one who cut off his ears and nose is Mahallaka.
The karmic causes from past lives are like this, not just from today.
